(1) Janet had it right: Your comment was needlessly judgmental. And the judgment was based on an assumption that I'm sure is largely inaccurate: Parents (of all stripes) who use these machines do so largely as _complement_ or _supplement_ to numerous other activities, all geared towards getting the baby the right environment. My baby had colic, as well, and while he was able to fall asleep in our arms and during our shushing, the minute we put him down, he'd awaken again. We used this machine for a while in order to help _add_ to the sleep environment we wanted. As a parent, you should get that concept.

(2) @ TrixieB; you're right, it's not a good idea to condition the baby to _only_ sleep with white noise. And a baby will adapt, as you point out.

My post-colic child now falls to sleep easily without white noise, but I'm sympathetic to a parent who's at wit's end to get their child to fall to sleep. Sleeping "like a baby" is an accurate term, but only after the point where the baby's brain has developed sufficiently to _enable_ him to have deep sleep (three months). Deep sleep occurs between 35 and 55 minutes _after_ the baby falls asleep. The period before that, the baby is in REM sleep, among other parts of the cycle, which is a period of light sleep and easy arousal. A child awakened at this point may then stay awake for hours more. Hence the use of white noise machines to help muffle, say, urban cacophany, to help the baby get to the Land of Nod.

Should McConnell become majority leader the first thing he would do would be to eliminate the filibuster--for everything, not just judicial nominees.
Mandatory minimum sentences are just that--a minimum from which the judge may not deviate downward.  It does not prohibit the judge from imposing a  sentence harsher than the minimum.

Did judges really lack discretion in how they applied those mandatory minimum things? There is anecdotal evidence that some judges used their discretion to impose harsher sentences than they were required to. Read some of the accounts of the sentencing of Kemba Smith and another woman pardoned by Bill Clinton. Moreover, for a scholarly exploration, see Sudbury's “Celling Black Bodies: Black Women in the Global Prison Industrial Complex,” Feminist Review, 70 (2002), 57-74. Sudbury begins her commentary with an anecdote about a mother and daughter being sentenced. The older woman was not directly involved in drugs, but was given a longer sentence because, the court reasoned, she should have known about her daughter's involvement in drugs and because the younger woman was pregnant. I believe Sudbury's account was in a European court, but is nonetheless instructive about what obtained in the US. Judges merit a closer examination because the mandatory-minimum policy (and War on Drugs) disparately impacted black women, catapulting them to twice the incarceration rate (and number) of both white and Hispanic women combined. Unfortunately, the official storytellers, primarily media, divert attention from this female-to-female comparison by limiting the dialogue to black male incarceration. Why are we forced to choose between the two?

You may be right about the text of the article, but I think you missed the title. "Birth by C-Section May Raise Obesity Risk." There is a strong implication there that biases your reading of the rest of the article. It is undeniable that this was the intended effect even if the author was careful to not explicitly state a correlation/causation fallacy in the body of the article.

@Susan: THANK YOU for taking the time to be a voice of reason and explain to those who made the various comments that precede yours that they lack any understanding of research, science, and what this study is saying.

I find many of these comments alarming/alarmist. I read and reread the story, and nowhere do I read that C-sections cause obesity. Scientists have analyzed the data at hand and have found a correlation that suggest a direction for further study.

And the correlation is significant but modest. For some reason, children born this way are oftener, about 1/4 of the time, obese or overweight as adults. It's something to think about and explore further, and something for the rest of us to keep our eyes and ears attuned to for more information in the future.

It's not a personal indictment of anyone, and also not refuted by anyone's anecdote. The problem is not with the article, but with the poor science understanding of many readers. The author is not making a causation claim, and the competent reader will not find or even infer one.

As a clinical social worker who has dealt with suicidal patients and the stress that leads them to suicidal thoughts and behaviors, I have questions about the validity of this study right off the sweet spot of the bat. In fact, it's a puffball. The military has been exposed in recent years as attempting to dismiss PTSD diagnoses -- in fact, discouraging their clinicians from diagnosing it -- in order to deny the stress of war or military dysfunction as having any role in the disabling distress troops have developed. The Nation has been through this scandalous dismissal and marginalization of troops already. It's been well documented that military psychologists have been encouraged to avoid a diagnosis of PTSD in favor of diagnosing a pre-existing personality disorder in those who suffer ill symptoms and serious behavioral problems following combat. This practice is shameful. Dig deeper, regardless of what "distinguished" journal has put out this report.

"The suggestion that soldiers who kill themselves had suicidal tendencies before they enlisted implies military men and women could go through multiple deployments to war zones and be relatively unscathed by their experiences."

No, the suggestion doesn't imply that...there are pre-enlistment, pre-deployment, deployment, and post-deployment risk and resilience factors investigated in this study. Some soldiers do go through deployment and are relatively unscathed. It's important to know what contributes to resilience as well as what contributes to risk. Your statement here isn't too logical. Clearly, the soldiers who committed suicide in this study--whether they had pre-deployment risk factors or not--did not emerge relatively unscathed! What the preliminary results show us is that programs viewing all new recruits as a blank slate have put soldiers at risk. Programs that have waited until after deployment to examine soldiers' mental health or that have focused on characteristics preparing soldiers only for specific aspects of deployment have caused incredible harm. With a large cohort study that has the power to measure subtle risks, we can finally begin to hold people accountable for this.

You are right on in your statement.  I have two friends who are recently retired from the Special Forces; one an Army Ranger and one a Navy Seal.  Both men were snipers.  Neither had PTSD prior to enlistment, but both have PTSD after years in Special Forces.  I am a civilian and I have PTSD due to an accident that almost killed me and other major trauma.  None of us had mental disorders prior to the trauma in our lives.  Nightmares, flashbacks, insomnia, anxiety, depression, isolation, all came after the trauma.  The military in combat have been traumatized by years of war in numerous countries.  It is the horror of combat that creates PTSD and suicidal tendencies, not because people have mental disorders prior to combat or trauma.  The military is trying to come up with excuses for the suicides, but it is the horrors of war that bring normal people to deadly suicide solutions.

I often wonder, too, how difficult it must be to go from combat and then transition back into civilian life.  Our "civilian life" is so divorced from what happens on the battlefield that the transitions has to be for some a very lonely journey.

I find it impossible to believe that spending long stretches of time in the brutal stress of a combat environment, then trying to return home to a "normal" life, would not have serious adverse psychological effects on most human beings.

Add to that the rate of post-traumatic stress syndrome, estimated at between 15 and 35 per cent of veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and the conclusions of the studies reported in this article seem ludicrous.

The suggestion that soldiers who kill themselves had suicidal tendencies before they enlisted implies military men and women could go through multiple deployments to war zones and be relatively unscathed by their experiences.

Good points -- and well stated! Here is my quick and recent observation about participation ribbons ...

Last summer, my six year old started attending a local chess club and playing in some of the Sunday tournaments with kids 5-12 years old. While he had been enjoying and playing the game for almost a year and had been winning games often at his elementary school -- it was a quite hard going to the chess club and playing against *very skilled* kids who studied the game a lot.

The tournament participation ribbons/medals my son received were meaningful to him. He was proud of them, even.

No, they did not make him feel like a 'winner' after losing match after match -- believe me -- he knew he was losing. Rather, he was proud of those participation medals because they supported his interest in chess and taking on a new and big challenge. They sort of said to him, "Good effort - hang in there - keep studying and having fun'.

I agree with other commentators -- there comes a point when kids won't generally find the participation trophies/ribbons meaningful and will be fine with focusing on the 1st-3rd (or whatever) competitive honors. However, I think they have a place in the context of activities for young children -- and they shouldn't be automatically discounted as just another way we 'coddle' our kids at every turn.

Well, the structure of the functions would be like this (depending on the fact that picking the devil's penny is undesirable; this makes this inapplicable as-is to your first variation of the problem). Let the first argument be the box with money that we happen to open, the second argument be the remaining boxes with money, and the third argument be our winnings so far:

f1(v0, {}, w) = v0
i.e., we opened the box with v0 money, so we get an additional reward of v0, and we won't want to open the final box.
f2(v0, {v1}, w) = v0 plus {(f1(v1, {}, w plus v0) - (w plus v0))/2 if this is greater than 0, 0 otherwise}
i.e., we got the v0 money, and if we expect to win more money from continuing to open another box afterwards, we add the expected rewards from that. Note that I left out the f1 before because it's just an identity.
f3(v0, {v1,v2}, w) = v0 plus {(f2(v1, {v2}, w plus v0) plus f2(v2, {v1}, w plus v0) - (w plus v0))/3 if this is greater than 0, 0 otherwise}
And so on.

The additions in the right-hand side of each equation come from the uniform distribution of possible boxes we might open if we choose to open another box.

Question about the formulation of your second variation: If the player is in a state with negative winnings, and then they open the devil's penny, is their money returned to them? If so, then again the assumption above that picking the devil's penny is always undesirable is broken, and so these functions (f1 in particular) would be not quite correct.

While the USA is trying to 're-invent the wheel', our backwards greedy corporate groupthink here is bankrupting the population.

Much the same applies in the UK NHS. My relatives there (now ranging from 87- 91 years old) and those now deceased (ranging up to 99 years old) received good care from the NHS (whose 'network' in US-insurance speak is essentially all physicians and surgeons in the country). This included hip replacement as soon as medically necessary, a pacemaker, a pacemaker defibrillator, etc. The only time waiting was an issue (or would have been in the US) was when my father visited a US cardiologist, who recommended a pacemaker. His UK doctor said not on the NHS, though if you want to go privately it could be done. He cited statistics: you are 85, any surgery or anaesthesia is risky for you. I estimate the risk of serious surgical complications (stroke or death) as 10%. The risk of heart failure resulting in serious complications or death in the next 2 years is about 2%, but it rises over time. I'll see you at the end of each 12 months. After 2 years he said it was time to do it, and it was done two weeks later. The entire cost was about $30, and that was a taxi.
Home visits by doctors are common when the patient is really ill. (No charge.) My eldest relative receives 4 visits daily from health aides of various kinds, because he suffered a stroke. (No charge.) He is still in his own home.

I have many colleagues in Germany. They are physicians and psychologists. They all have private solo or small practices. There are some geographic restrictions on specialists in each area, but it is based on patient need.

Germany is a primarily single payer system although there are numerous insurance plans. They are not primarily for-profit, however. Medical care in Germany is excellent. If you are accepted, medical school is free. Physicians are highly trained, more than US: MD's must also do PhD level research dissertations (not required in US). Medications and procedures are similar to, and often more advanced than US.

Health plans cover more services that US, including rehab, post-natal, post-surgery programs, etc. Each town has a mobile ambulance that goes to the home and provides most care; the ER's are used only for true emergencies. Of course all this is paid for by taxes but most citizens are quiet pleased with the care they receive. This system has existed for decades and is not related to employment, as in USA. There are no "networks"; you can choose any MD you want and stay for years if you want. There is little "corporate" medicine.

I have received some superb medical care there while visiting, and I know my colleagues' abilities and training are excellent. Paperwork is simplified (even in Germany!) and costs are reasonable since there are not huge exec salaries, lobbying costs, advertising costs, network maintenance costs, etc.

Can we learn from this?

The difference is that the United States truly is a force for good in the world, not pure good, but on balance good.  Most of Europe, the Philipines, China, Japan, South Korea, Panama, Iraq, and Afghanistan are all better off for our intervention, better off for our exceptional role in the world.  And Russia is a force for evil.  Just ask the Poles, the Ukrainians, the Czechs, the Finns, the Hungarians, the Ukrainians, the Afghans, or the Georgians.

The discussion of Ilyin, Solovyov and Berdyaev is fascinating. Like the United States, Russia apparently has a deeply held ethos of 'Manifest Destiny'. To invoke a similar ethos, China continues to see itself as the appropriate 'Center of the World'.

What this teaches us is that all great powers, Russia included, invoke themes that reflect their vision of greatness. It is important to understand these themes and visions and to take them into account when making policy. At the same time, Russia, China and the United States are all motivated by Real Politick-- the pragmatic imperatives of power. Both Real Politick and national themes and visions must be accounted for on the global stage.
